awd_titl_txt: GOALI: A comprehensive study of nonlinear phenomena in multimode optical fibers for enhancing the performance of optical communication systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Title:  
GOALI: A comprehensive study of nonlinear phenomena in multimode optical fibers for enhancing the performance of optical communication systems

Abstract:
The use of optical fibers for transmitting information over long distances has made the spread of the Internet possible. The advent of a technique, known as wavelength-division multiplexing, helped in increasing the capacity of fiber-based communication systems during the decades of the 1990s and 2000s. However, current systems will not be able to meet the continuing increase in the data rates fueled by such activities as on-line learning and video streaming. A new technique, called space-division multiplexing (SDM), is being studied in the laboratories worldwide to meet this demand. It makes use of optical fibers that are designed to support multiple spatial modes either by using a single large-size core or several narrower cores, each supporting a single mode. However, before the SDM technique can be implemented in real systems, it is necessary to understand the impact of various nonlinear effects occurring inside a multimode fiber, or a multicore fiber whose cores are coupled in view of their close proximity. This is what the proposed research project will accomplish.
The main goal of the proposed research is to develop and implement new theoretical and numerical tools for modeling the simultaneous propagation of multiple data streams through SDM inside a multicore or a multimode fiber. These tools will be used to develop a fundamental understanding of how each SDM channel is affected by other co-propagating channels in the presence of various nonlinear effects such as self-phase modulation, cross-phase modulation, stimulated Raman scattering, and four-wave mixing. Even though the modes of an ideal fiber should not be coupled to each other, modes of any realistic multimode fiber will experience some random coupling. A major objective of this GOALI project is to understand the origin of this coupling and study how it impacts various nonlinear effects and the performance of SDM systems. In this effort, our industrial partner would be of immense help because of the recent experiments performed at Bell Labs that have quantified the extent of random mode coupling in six-mode fibers. The project has both the fundamental and applied aspects. An improved understanding of the nonlinear phenomena in multimode fibers is of fundamental importance and should help the next generation of graduate students and scientists in coming up with new device ideas. The study of nonlinear effects should also help in designing the future SDM systems. Two graduate students will work with the P.I. on this GOALI project as a part of their Ph.D. thesis. Both of them will spend time each year at the industrial site so that they can acquire valuable industrial experience. This kind of training of the graduate students is ideal for developing the work force for the U.S. telecommunication industry.

por.por_cntn:
The relentless quest for increasing the telecommunication network capacity to meet the exponential growth of the data transfer on the Internet has put a huge pressure on the existing optical networks. Studies carried out over the last 20 years have indicated that we are approaching the capacity limit of single-mode optical fibers set by the fiber?s nonlinearity. To overcome this fundamental capacity limit, the use of space-division multiplexing (SDM) has been proposed through simultaneous transmission of telecom channels over multiple modes of the same fiber using multicore or multimode optical fibers.

Before the SDM technique can be implemented in real systems, one need to understand the limitations imposed by different types of linear and nonlinear cross-talks that are likely to occur inside multimode fibers because of spatial overlapping and coupling of different modes. One objective of this project was to develop new theoretical and numerical tools for modeling simultaneous propagation of multiple optical fields inside a multimode fiber. The second objective was to use these tools to study the performance of SDM communication systems based on multimode fibers and to understand the intermodal nonlinear effects and their potential applications.

To meet these objectives, we developed a computer code capable of modeling propagation of telecom signals inside multimode fibers. The code takes into account multiple spatial modes of an optical fiber as well as the two orthogonally polarized components of each spatial mode of this fiber. The code was tested extensively and used to reproduce the known results in specific special cases. We have used this code to study the performance of a few specific SDM communication systems. An important result we obtained shows that the linear mode coupling, unavoidable when the cores of a multimode fibers are not too far apart, can actually help by reducing the impact of the nonlinear effects that invariably degrade modern telecom systems. Recent experiments have supported this conclusion.

In the case of a multimode fiber containing a single large-size core, linear coupling among its modes is typically random in nature because of variations in the core shape and size along the fiber?s length during its manufacturing. Modeling nonlinear transmission in such fibers is time-consuming because it requires hundreds (even thousands) of realizations of random coupling to calculate the averaged quantities of practical interest. Thus, it is important to find averaged equations whose use can reduce the computational times by orders of magnitude. We were able to derive the averaged multimode equations that are valid in the weak, strong, or intermediate regime of linear mode coupling. These equations should prove valuable for modeling the future SDM-based telecommunication systems.

The other outcomes of this project are related to the investigation of nonlinear phenomena in both the step-index and graded-index type multimode fibers. We investigated propagation of ultrashort pulses inside such fibers after including both the Kerr and Raman nonlinearities of silica glass. We found the conditions under which a multimode soliton can form inside a graded-index fiber. We found that the Raman-induced frequency shift is enhanced considerably inside such a fiber compared to a single-mode fiber. We used our numerical code for explaining how the energy of a femtosecond pulse can be transferred to a neighboring mode through the Raman process. Our results are in excellent agreement with the experimental data and are likely to be useful for a variety of applications making use of multimode fibers.
